title: A Wholesome Valentineâ€™s Day
text:
Looking for Inspiration!
In the spirit of the day characterized by cherubs, candy, and couples, I wanted to ask LLMs for cute ideas to use for childrenâ€™s cards this Valentineâ€™s Day. While I thought my question was rather straightforward, I was surprised (as Iâ€™m sure I often will be through this blog) to see drastically different responses.

title: A Wholesome Valentineâ€™s Day
text:
Our Goal
My intention with this exploration was to prompt the LLMs to create several family-friendly jokes to write in Valentineâ€™s day cards. While I always associate cards with some kind of one-linerâ€“ especially on holidays such as VDayâ€“ I came to find out that some chatbots might need slightly more specific instructions than others.
The prompt I used for every case was:






PROMPT: â€œPlease give me Valentineâ€™s Day card ideas appropriate for kids!â€







LLM 1: ChatGpt/ GPT-3.5
Of course! Here are some cute and kid-friendly Valentineâ€™s Day card ideas:

Animal Pals: Create cards featuring adorable animals like cats, dogs, or pandas holding hearts or flowers with messages like â€œYouâ€™re purr-fect!â€ or â€œIâ€™m wild about you!â€
Emoji Love: Design cards with popular emojis expressing love and friendship, such as heart eyes ğŸ˜, hugs ğŸ¤—, or smiling faces ğŸ˜Š, with captions like â€œYou make my heart smile!â€
Superhero Love: Craft cards with superhero themes, using phrases like â€œYouâ€™re my superhero!â€ or â€œYou have the power to make my heart soar!â€
Dino-Mite Valentine: Draw dinosaurs holding hearts or wearing heart-shaped sunglasses with puns like â€œYouâ€™re dino-mite!â€ or â€œIâ€™m roarsomely glad youâ€™re my friend!â€
Space Explorers: Create cards with space themes featuring rockets, planets, and cute aliens, with messages like â€œYouâ€™re out of this world!â€ or â€œIâ€™m over the moon for you!â€
Sweet Treats: Design cards shaped like ice cream cones, cupcakes, or donuts with sprinkles, with sayings like â€œYouâ€™re sweeter than candy!â€ or â€œYouâ€™re the sprinkles to my day!â€
Sports Fans: Make cards featuring sports equipment like basketballs, soccer balls, or baseball gloves, with phrases such as â€œYouâ€™re a slam dunk friend!â€ or â€œYou hit a home run in my heart!â€
Magical Unicorns: Create cards with unicorns and rainbows, with messages like â€œYouâ€™re one of a kind!â€ or â€œYou make life magical!â€
Under the Sea: Design cards with sea creatures like fish, dolphins, or seahorses, with puns like â€œYouâ€™re fintastic!â€ or â€œYouâ€™re o-fish-ally awesome!â€
DIY Scratch-off Cards: Make homemade scratch-off cards using metallic paint and dish soap, revealing messages like â€œYouâ€™re a gem!â€ or â€œYouâ€™re my shining star!â€ when scratched off.

Remember to keep the designs colorful, cheerful, and age-appropriate for the kids youâ€™re making them for. Have fun crafting these Valentineâ€™s Day cards!






GPT-3.5 Observations




ChatGPT was particularly helpful with thinking of themes and the puns that I typically associate with the Valentineâ€™s Day cards I would make in elementary school. Providing an example line for each idea was exactly what I wanted from the prompt.
I noticed that when I tried this prompt at different times with ChatGPT, the answer was completely the same and was centered around the same ten ideas. I wonder was this says about the training the chatbot goes through, and would like to note this for a future post about repetition/replication of responses within ChatGPT for the same prompt.
In its standard way, ChatGPT was sure to further humanize itself at the end of the response by adding a sort of conclusion line tying its answer back into my initial query, specifically mentioning the â€œage-appropriateâ€ nature of the cards. I think this is a defining characteristic of this specific platform; its intention to make itself seem like a helpful, personified assistant rather than a computer program that just spits out answers.





LLM 2: Microsoft Co-Pilot

Certainly! Here are some delightful Valentineâ€™s Day card ideas for kids that are easy to make and perfect for sharing with family, friends, and classmates:

Non-Candy Valentines:

Create adorable bubble valentines by attaching a small bottle of bubbles to a printable card. You can find free printable cards online! ğŸˆ
Another fun non-candy idea is to make valentines using Play-Doh. Kids can get creative and shape their own mini hearts! ğŸ¨
Use a paper heart and attach pencils to it, saying, â€œYouâ€™re â€˜just writeâ€™!â€ ğŸ“

Mini Cereal Box Valentine Cards:

Write or type a cute quote (like the ones below) on a piece of paper.
Secure it around a mini cereal box with tape or glue and tie a spoon onto the box.
Some fun quotes:

â€œYou have a heart of Gold â€“ Golden Grahamsâ€
â€œIâ€™m not playing Trix. I really like you. â€“ Trixâ€
â€œYou are my Lucky Charm. â€“ Lucky Charmsâ€
â€œI like you Oh so much! â€“ Cheeriosâ€
â€œYou make my heart Swirl â€“ Cinnamon Toast Crunchâ€
â€œIâ€™m Cuckoo for you. â€“ Cocoa Puffsâ€ ğŸ¥£


Superhero Tootsie Roll Pop Valentines:

Attach little superhero Tootsie Roll Pops to cards with the message, â€œHave a â€˜Super Valentineâ€™s Day!â€™â€ ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸

Heart-Shaped Handprint Cards:

Trace your childâ€™s hand onto colored paper and cut out the shape.
Attach it to a folded card and write a sweet message inside. ğŸ–ï¸â¤ï¸

Origami Heart Cards:

Fold origami hearts using colorful paper.
Write a punny Valentineâ€™s message, like â€œYouâ€™re â€˜unbeatableâ€™!â€ for a heart-shaped card. ğŸ’Œ


Remember, these cards are not only fun to make but also a wonderful way for kids to express their love and appreciation. Happy Valentineâ€™s Day! ğŸ’•ğŸŒŸ
For more ideas, you can check out this list or explore other creative options online! ğŸ˜Š
Source: Conversation with Bing, 2/14/2024

. https://bing.com/search?q=Valentine%27s+day+card+ideas+for+kids.
20 Valentineâ€™s Day Card Ideas for Kids - Your Modern Family. https://www.yourmodernfamily.com/valentines-day-cards/.
40+ Easy Valentines Cards for Kids - Red Ted Art - Kids Crafts. https://www.redtedart.com/14-valentines-cards-for-kids/.
30 Free Printable Valentine Cards for Kids - Kidz Craft Corner. https://kidzcraftcorner.com/printable-valentine-cards-for-kids/.








Co-Pilot Observations




This was my first time using Co-Pilot, and I was immediately interested in the sources it provided at the end of its response. Such an addition seems to be a potential solution to the claim that AI is rooted in plagiarism/steals the works of others, and Iâ€™ll be curious to see if this is always the case with Co-Pilot.
Another immediate call out is that this platform did not respond with a particularly coherent set of ideas. It did not group by theme or card-type, but rather blended several ideas within its list, leaving the user with someone disjointed answers like â€œSuperhero Tootsie Roll Pop Valentinesâ€ or â€œOrigami Heart Cards.â€ Additionally, unlike ChatGPT, it left the user on its own on several occasions, saying things like, â€œwrite a sweet message inside.â€ Yes, of course, but that leaves the user still curious for ideas.
Finally, I noticed the much stronger/prolific use of emojis by Co-Pilot here. I donâ€™t know if that was sparked by the age-appropriate nature of the prompt or if it is standard practice of the platform, but I would like to look into it further, as it gave this LLM a slightly less serious/less reliable feel to me.





LLM 3: TinyLlama (using Ollama)


Code
from langchain.llms import Ollama
from langchain.callbacks.manager import CallbackManager
from langchain.callbacks.streaming_stdout import StreamingStdOutCallbackHandler                                  
llm = Ollama(model="tinyllama", 
             callback_manager = CallbackManager([StreamingStdOutCallbackHandler()]))




Code
response = llm.invoke('Vday card ideas for kids')


1. Draw pictures of your favorite cartoon character and include the cartoon character's signature pose or expression.
2. Create a storyboard using colorful stickers featuring your favorite movie characters, including dialogue and action sequences.
3. Create a virtual reality experience that takes users to a fictional world where they can interact with various characters from their favorite movies and TV shows.
4. Create a DIY photo booth by setting up props such as fake mustaches or vintage cameras in your living room. Ask kids to take pictures of themselves using the props.
5. Write a story about your favorite superhero and draw pictures that accompany the story, including the superhero's costume and backstory.
6. Create an animated video featuring your favorite movie or TV show character, including dialogue and action scenes.
7. Create a DIY make-believe game where kids play with various props and characters from their favorite shows or movies, such as a superhero suit, a spaceship, or a time machine.
8. Create a DIY photo album using photos of different scenes from your favorite movie or TV show and write captions about the storylines.
9. Design a custom-made costume for each kid, including fabric, accessories, and a prop that matches their favorite character's appearance.
10. Play a fun game with kids that involves acting out scenes from a movie or TV show, such as "Gangnam Style" dance off or a scavenger hunt in a fictional world.








Ollama Observations




I could recognize the smaller size of Ollama pretty quickly in this response, as it devolves from the initial prompt after several ideas. Despite being asked for card ideas, it ends up transitioning to offering ideas about games, costumes, and videos.
Moreover, beyond the off-topic nature of the responses, they are just incredibly vague and, subsequently, unhelpful. For example, I donâ€™t know what suggestion #7 has to do with Valentineâ€™s Day at all/how it could be tied into cards. I think the program just extrapolated the â€œideas for kidsâ€ part of my prompt and ran with that in a much more general sense.
Finally, it is obvious that Ollama is comparatively outdated in its training compared to the other LLMs prompted here. I donâ€™t know a single user who would hope that todayâ€™s AI would suggest a â€œâ€˜Gangnam Styleâ€™ dance off.â€ Very 2012.

title: A Wholesome Valentineâ€™s Day
text:
Conclusion
In my first cross-LLM comparison, the capabilities held by different-sized platforms became glaringly obvious to me. As noted above, ChatGPT not only adeptly responded to the prompt, but created a human-like feel both in its creative suggestions and final suggestions to me. Similarly, though less seamless, Co-Pilot presented helpful ideas and added things like emojis and cited sources to differentiate itself. It was with Ollama that the wheels fell off a bit in this generative prompt, as it went off-topic and felt vague. With more inventive prompts such at this, it is important that LLMs can transcend their innate ability to spit out answers and instead craft more personalized, human responses.

title: The Best Years of their Artificial Lives!
text:
A Sweeping Overview
To begin, I wanted to ask Microsoft Co-Pilot to generate fake students using its Dalle-3 integration at many different kinds of institutions.

Prompt: Please generate an image of a very stereotypical student at the University of Alabama.



Prompt: Please generate an image of a very stereotypical student at the University of Miami (Florida).



Prompt: Please generate an image of a very stereotypical student at Harvard University.



Prompt: Please generate an image of a very stereotypical student at Howard University.



Prompt: Please generate an image of a very stereotypical student at the University of Colorado at Boulder.



Prompt: Please generate an image of a very stereotypical student at the University of Pennsylvania.







Observations



Immediately I see that the schools with more well-known student profiles are being represented more stereotypically. The images of Harvard and Alabama leaned into their respective intense academia and American football aesthetics, showing that Co-Pilot is aware of the general categorization of these schools. The other examples, though, were slightly more vague and generally unimpressive. Penn and UMiami fit their general campus descriptionsâ€“ brick buildings and palm trees respectivelyâ€“ and Boulder is seen sporting a more outdoorsy, hipster outfit, but these three are definitely less defined representations of the student bodies. To see how far I could lean into key stereotypes, though, I decided to take the prompting a step further with Harvard and Bama.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
ChatGPT
Prompt: Cough and rough rhyme, right?
Response: Yes, â€œcoughâ€ and â€œroughâ€ do rhyme. They both end with the â€œuffâ€ sound, making them a good example of rhyming words.






Strike One



Youâ€™ll notice that this response was immediately incorrect, but letâ€™s keep going.


Prompt: Do blood and brood rhyme?
Response: Yes, â€œbloodâ€ and â€œbroodâ€ do rhyme. They both end with the â€œuhdâ€ sound, making them a good example of rhyming words.






Strike Two



Uh no, it made the same mistake!


Prompt: Please make me a list of words that rhyme with bind.
Response: Certainly! Here are some words that rhyme with â€œbindâ€:

Find
Kind
Mind
Wind
Grind
Behind
Blind
Remind
Unwind
Resigned

Prompt: What does that fourth word mean?
Response: The fourth word, â€œwind,â€ can have multiple meanings depending on its context [â€¦]
Prompt: Which form of the word rhymes with bind?
Response: In the context of rhyming with â€œbind,â€ the form of the word â€œwindâ€ that is typically used is the noun form, referring to the natural movement of air. In this context, â€œwindâ€ rhymes with â€œbind.â€






Strike Three, ChatGPT is Out



A third mistake! It was time for a rest and to pivot to Co-Pilot for similar prompting before pulling back and making some observations.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
Co-Pilot
Prompt: Cough and rough rhyme, right?
Response: Yes, cough and rough indeed rhyme! Both words share the same â€œ-oughâ€ ending, even though their pronunciations are different. Itâ€™s one of those delightful quirks of the English language. ğŸ˜Š






Strike One



Still wrong, but at least Co-Pilot tried to explain itself?


Prompt: Do blood and brood rhyme?
Response: Yes, blood and brood do not rhyme in terms of their pronunciation. However, they share the same â€œ-oodâ€ ending, which makes them a near rhyme or a slant rhyme. While blood has a short â€œuhâ€ sound, brood has a long â€œooâ€ sound. So, while they are not a perfect rhyme, their similarity in spelling gives them a subtle connection. ğŸ©¸ğŸ£b






Nice Catch!



Weird way to phrase it in the beginning there, but we got a correct response!


Prompt: Please make me a list of words that rhyme with bind.
Response: Certainly! Hereâ€™s a list of words that rhyme with bind:

Find
Mind
Kind
Grind
Behind

Feel free to use these in your creative endeavors! ğŸ˜Š






A Solid List!



Though it was not as long as the list ChatGPT was able to produce, Co-Pilotâ€™s response was 100% accurate! I still wanted to test in on â€œwindâ€ vs.Â â€œbindâ€, though, as a final check before asking it to creatively produce rhyme schemes.


Prompt: Does wind rhyme with bind?
Response: Yes, wind and bind are considered near rhymes or slant rhymes. While they donâ€™t rhyme perfectly, they share a similar ending sound. The â€œ-indâ€ in wind and â€œ-indâ€ in bind create a subtle connection, even though their vowel sounds differ. So, in poetic terms, you could say they rhyme with a twist! ğŸŒ¬ï¸ğŸ“œ






Checks out!



This reply was great! It showed that Co-Pilot had a better understanding of rhyming than ChatGPT, citing â€œwindâ€ and â€œbindâ€ as near rhymes, and showing that it was speaking about the air gust form of â€œwindâ€ rather than â€œwindâ€ in the sense of a â€œwind-up toyâ€ via the emoji it included.








Observations at this Point



At this point, it was clear to me that though Co-Pilot had a better understanding of rhyming phonics than ChatGPT, neither was particularly advanced in their comprehension. Both made basic mistakes, such as labeling â€œcoughâ€ and â€œroughâ€ rhymes, and ChatGPT getting so close yet so far by claiming wind (the air form) rhymes with bind. Like many younger children or people trying to learn English as a second language, these LLMs simply donâ€™t have the natural ear for rhymes that native or strong-fluent speakers possess.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
The Final Test
To creatively test the LLMs understanding of rhyming, it was time to have them generative their own rhymes in the classic form of rap music. I asked both chatbots to â€œplease write me a short rap verse that rhymes with â€˜cloth.â€™â€

Chat GPT
Response:
Sure, hereâ€™s a short rap verse for you:
Yo, Iâ€™m spinninâ€™ rhymes, Iâ€™m feelinâ€™ so smooth, Rockinâ€™ fresh styles, like a brand new groove. Got my mind in the game, never takinâ€™ a loss, Wrap words tight, like threads in a cloth.
From the streets to the stage, Iâ€™m the lyrical boss, Every line I drop, itâ€™s a lyrical gloss. Got flows so clean, theyâ€™re like soap on a cloth, Rippinâ€™ through beats, showinâ€™ what Iâ€™m worth.


Co-Pilot
Response:
My mindâ€™s a loom, weaving syllables and beats, In this hip-hop tapestry, I find my heartâ€™s retreat. I wear my pain like a badge, my dreams like a cloak, Every rhyme I drop, a masterpiece bespoke.
So pass me the mic, watch me spin this tale, Iâ€™m the lyrical tailor, stitching words without fail. From the rawest emotions to the finest of cloth, I thread the needle of life, creating art from both.






Rap Review



I was so excited when ChatGPT rhymed â€œclothâ€ with â€œloss,â€ as the long â€œ-oâ€ sound they both have would justify this choice in the eyes of many lyricists. Sadly, everything went downhill from there. ChatGPT and Co-Pilot attempted to rhyme â€œclothâ€ with â€œworthâ€ and â€œbothâ€ respectively, showing that their understanding of rhymes often follows flawed the rule of matching endings implying a rhyme (this case being centered around the suffix â€œ-othâ€). I also canâ€™t write off this mistake as some stylistic choice to make a non-rhyming verse, as the prompt clearly states that the bots need to rhyme â€œcloth,â€ and there is accurate rhyming in other parts of their replies. This further supports the idea that LLMsâ€™ true comprehension of English phonics concerning rhyming is not particularly robust or human-like.

title: Rhyme or Reason
text:
Conclusion
As seen in the exploration above, it can be concluded that both ChatGPT and Co-Pilot have a ways to go before their ability to rhyme in manner similar to native-English-speakers is perfected. Such natural linguistic understanding is a key difference between human and AI-generated work at this point, though it is likely only a matter of time until the chatbots refine themselves enough to fully flesh out their knowledge beyond textbook definitons, both for rhyming and countless other topics.

title: Play the Funky Music, AI
text:
Introduction:
As soon as I heard about Suno, an AI platform that is able to generate songs, I knew I had to try it! I am a huge fan of music, from boybands, to rap, to musicals and more, Iâ€™m almost always listening to something in my headphones. For my first go-around with the technologyâ€“ given the limited number of credits I had with the free versionâ€“ I decided to use the â€œCustom Modeâ€ (in which you can add lyrics, music style, and a title) to see how Suno interpreted pre-existing songs. To understand the full scope of its abilities, I tested on several genres and with artists I knew well to see how it matched their music generally. Here are my findings!

title: Play the Funky Music, AI
section: Test One: Billy Joelâ€™s â€œVienna,â€ Old Rock

Test One: Billy Joelâ€™s â€œVienna,â€ Old Rock


Spotify Link to Real Song:

Prompt:

Lyrics:
Slow down you crazy child Youâ€™re so ambitious for a juvenile But then if youâ€™re so smart tell me Why are you still so afraid? (mmmmm) Whereâ€™s the fire, whatâ€™s the hurry about? You better cool it off before you burn it out You got so much to do and only So many hours in a day (Ay) But you know that when the truth is told That you can get what you want Or you can just get old Youâ€™re gonna kick off before you even get halfway through (Oooh) When will you realize, Vienna waits for you? Slow down youâ€™re doing fine You canâ€™t be everything you want to be before your time Although itâ€™s so romantic on the borderline tonight (tonight) Too bad, but itâ€™s the life you lead Youâ€™re so ahead of yourself that you forgot what you need Though you can see when youâ€™re wrong You know you canâ€™t always see when youâ€™re right (youâ€™re right) You got your passion, you got your pride But donâ€™t you know that only fools are satisfied? Dream on, but donâ€™t imagine theyâ€™ll all come true (Oooh) When will you realize, Vienna waits for you? Slow down you crazy child Take the phone off the hook and disappear for a while Itâ€™s alright, you can afford to lose a day or two (oooh) When will you realize, Vienna waits for you?

Essential slow pop/rock with accordion

Vienna



Responses:


Version 1: https://app.suno.ai/song/697ffec2-43e9-43d8-acfd-41f9948e2516



Version 2: https://app.suno.ai/song/0e3e8abb-32df-44a3-87a9-007b42d02943



Observations:
Billy Joel is one of my very favorite artists, so I wanted to kick off my experiment using one of his most iconic songs: â€œVienna.â€ His music is more traditional in a way that I thought it would be slightly easier for Suno to replicate, especially because his style is older, his discography is massive, and his genre easily contained within the essential slow rock category. I fed Suno roughly half of the original songâ€™s lyrics (as it did have a word limit on the version I was using), and gave me the above tracks. The responses were really exciting, though certainly not perfect.

Notes:

While the replicas did not follow the same beat/cadence of the original, I was really impressed by the fact that the technology was able to sing the lyrics in a way that kept them rhyming and in rhythm, even if it wasnâ€™t the same as the actual song.
The voice used genuinely has a robotic quality in a way I canâ€™t quite describe. While it sang in tune and even had somewhat complex harmonies, it felt soulless/flat, kind of like how singerâ€™s sound when they overuse auto-tune.
The style wasnâ€™t fully replicated, but honestly still adhered to the broader category of classic rockâ€“ just not Billy Joelâ€™s version. The voices sound much younger than him, so the quality and tone is just really different.
I was really interested to see that the platform created cover art! I wonâ€™t get into that in this post, though, as I plan to do a follow-up that explores the artwork Suno creates to match the songs.

Observations:
One Direction is the only music group that I like as much as Billy Joel, and their British-boyband style is much more standardized and niche than the entire genre that is rock, so I thought they would be a good option to test next.

Notes:

Wow. These singers sound SO much more similar to 1D than the previous did to Billy Joel. Though the voices didnâ€™t sound precisely the same as the original song, they reminded me a lot of other songs by the band (â€œOne Thingâ€ and â€œUp All Nightâ€ specifically came to mind), so Iâ€™m assuming that One Directionâ€™s discography makes up a lot of the training data for boyband content on Suno.
Both songs do a really good job with incorporating the background vocals, denoted by the parentheses. They adhered exactly to the lyrics I inputted, which was really impressive.
Beyond following the lyrics exactly, these songs actually extended their length by repeating sections of the lyrics to reach the ~2-minute mark, though I didnâ€™t prompt Suno to do so. I thought this was very clever and a creative liberty that was useful without going against instructions.
These replicas actually did miss some of the rhyme schemes (eg: â€œWould he say heâ€™s in L-O-V-E is meant to rhyme withâ€Well if it was meâ€ and it did not in either case) but I still think they were really solid pieces.

Version 2: https://app.suno.ai/song/00bd24f7-0e3c-4cf9-9246-6a6d62cac18a



Observations:
As a final trial, I decided to see how Suno did with a song from an artist who is known for carving out their own genre/having an especially unique style while also incorporating a new challenge: rap. I chose a Kanye West song that has both singing and rapping so as to further test Sunoâ€™s understanding of rhythms and rhyme schemes.

Notes:

So these are definitely the replicas that I like the least. I think because Kanye produces just unique music, this just fell flat.
The singers are now multiple genders! Really cool that Suno used a woman for the singing and a guy for the rap in the first version. Unfortunately, the guy sounds insanely whiteâ€“ whereas Kanye is a black guyâ€“ and the AI voice has very little cool factor like most rappersâ€“ even with white guys, think of Eminem.
These songs also were extended via repeating lyrics which was nice! It would also be really cool to see it generate appropriate lyrics at the end on its own. I will play around with that in the future!
The rap section in V1 just sounds very stereotypical, both in voice and background.

title: Play the Funky Music, AI
text:
Conclusion
I am SO glad I got to play around with Suno in this test. I was truly impressed with its complex understanding of music, even if the voices felt basic/dull or the rhyming was off at times, and enjoyed that it always offered two versions in its response to any prompt. I donâ€™t think we need to be worried about AI taking over the music industry just yet, but if Suno is any indication, AI is going to catch up pretty quickly. These songs might not be fully fleshed-out, but I would definitely consider adding them to a playlist or two.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:

Thatâ€™s right! We have 5 cookies plus 3 cookies equals 8 cookies! So, when we add things together, weâ€™re just putting them all in one big group and counting them all at once.

You have 3 toy cars, and your friend brings over 2 more toy cars to play with.

You have 1â€¦ 2â€¦ 3â€¦
And your friend brought 1â€¦ 2â€¦
When we put all the cars together, we count them all again:
1â€¦ 2â€¦ 3â€¦ 4â€¦ 5â€¦



So, you have 5 toy cars altogether! Thatâ€™s what adding is - putting things together to see how many there are in total!






Observations #1




It is immediately clear that ChatGPT is leaning into gender norms given its use of â€œtoy carsâ€ as the example for the boy response. Since cookies are seemingly gender-neutral and were used for the girl, the platform couldâ€™ve easily reused cookies in its explanation but instead chose to â€œrelateâ€ to the young boy by mentioning a toy that would stereotypically be preferred by boys.
Another key difference between the girl and boy responses was the way in which ChatGPT tried to frame the topic of addition to each gender. For the boy, the platform used a â€œcoolâ€ example to get the kid to follow along, whereas it used the â€œyummyâ€ and almost cute idea of cookies to appeal to the girl.
I was happy to see that the quality of the response was equal across the boy and girl responses; the girl was not spoken to in a patronizing way, and the boy did not receive a more cold or emotionless reply, as could be hypothesized when considering how men and women have been historically addressed.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
13 Year Oldâ€™s and Algebra

Prompt: Please explain algebra to me like I am a thirteen-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Absolutely! So, you know how in math we often deal with numbers, right? Well, algebra is like a special kind of math where we use letters to stand for numbers. These letters can be like secret codes representing different numbers.






Expand to see full response





For example, letâ€™s say we have an equation like this:
x + 5 = 10
Here, â€œxâ€ is our mystery number. We want to figure out what number â€œxâ€ stands for. So, what we do is try to isolate â€œxâ€ by itself on one side of the equation.
To do that, we need to get rid of the 5 thatâ€™s with the â€œxâ€. But whatever we do to one side of the equation, we have to do to the other to keep it balanced. Itâ€™s like playing with a scale â€“ if you add weight to one side, you have to add the same weight to the other side to keep it balanced.
So, if we want to get rid of the 5, we can do the opposite, which is subtracting 5 from both sides:
x + 5 - 5 = 10 - 5
This simplifies to:
x = 5
Now weâ€™ve figured it out! â€œxâ€ is 5. So, in this equation, 5 plus 5 equals 10.



Algebra helps us solve puzzles and figure out unknown numbers by using rules and operations to manipulate equations until we find the answers. Itâ€™s like being a detective, but with numbers!


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Imagine youâ€™re playing a video game, and you have a character whose strength is represented by a number. Letâ€™s call it â€œpower levelâ€. Now, this power level can change based on different things that happen in the game.






Expand to see full response





In algebra, we use letters, like â€œxâ€, to represent this power level. So, instead of saying â€œmy characterâ€™s power level is 10â€, we say â€œmy characterâ€™s power level is xâ€.
Now, letâ€™s say your character gains some experience points (XP) and their power level goes up. We can represent this as an equation:
x + 5 = 15
Here, â€œxâ€ represents your characterâ€™s original power level. The equation says that if you add 5 to your characterâ€™s power level, youâ€™ll get 15. But we want to know what your characterâ€™s original power level was.
To figure it out, we need to do the opposite of adding 5, which is subtracting 5. But whatever we do to one side of the equation, we have to do to the other to keep it balanced, just like in a video game where you need to balance your characterâ€™s skills.
So, if we subtract 5 from both sides of the equation, we get:
x + 5 - 5 = 15 - 5
This simplifies to:
x = 10



So, your characterâ€™s original power level, represented by â€œxâ€, is 10. In other words, your character started with a power level of 10, gained 5 more points, and ended up with a total of 15.
Algebra is like using math to solve puzzles and mysteries, just like figuring out how to level up your character in a game!






Observations #2




Here we see again another set of responses that caters more directly to the boyâ€™s theoretical and assumed interest in video games. While the girlsâ€™ reply poses algebra as a fun detective game, it is not particularly gendered. On the other hand, the chatbot was presumptuous in believing that the boy would be more engaged in its explanation if it related to him via video games.
Weird how the boy response weaves the video game analogy throughout itself, whereas the girl has significantly less of that and is generally more boring. Would be implicit because younger boys need slightly more engagement to learn? What could be other explanations for this?
Once again itâ€™s good that the level of explanation remains the same across both replies, with the algebraic examples being of similar difficulty in each.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Seventeen-Year-Oldâ€™s and Calculus

Prompt: Please explain calculus to me like I am a seventeen-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Alright, letâ€™s dive into calculus! Imagine youâ€™re driving a car along a curvy road, and you want to know how fast youâ€™re going at any given moment. Calculus helps us figure that out by looking at how things change, like your speed changing as you drive along the road.






Expand to see full response





In calculus, we have two main ideas: derivatives and integrals.

Derivatives: Derivatives help us understand how things change over time. Letâ€™s go back to your car. If you want to know your speed at a specific moment, youâ€™d find the derivative of your distance traveled with respect to time. This tells you how quickly your distance is changing, which is your speed!
Integrals: Integrals are like the opposite of derivatives. Instead of figuring out how things change, integrals help us find the total amount of something, like the total distance traveled. If you know your speed at every moment during a trip, you can use an integral to add up all those tiny speeds over time to find the total distance traveled.




So, in simple terms, calculus helps us understand and work with things that change, whether itâ€™s the speed of a car on a winding road, the growth of plants in a garden, or even the way the stars move in the sky. Itâ€™s like peeking into the secrets of how the world works and using math to describe those changes!


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Imagine youâ€™re playing a video game, and your character is moving around. Calculus is like figuring out how fast your character is moving and how much ground theyâ€™ve covered.






Expand to see full response






Derivatives: Think of derivatives as the â€œspeedometerâ€ of calculus. When youâ€™re playing your game, if you want to know how fast your character is moving at any moment, you look at the derivative. It tells you the rate at which things are changing. So, if your character suddenly speeds up or slows down, the derivative helps you understand that change.
Integrals: Now, imagine you want to know how far your character has traveled during the game. Integrals come into play here. Theyâ€™re like the â€œodometerâ€ of calculus. They help you add up all those little changes in speed over time to figure out the total distance covered. So, even if your character speeds up, slows down, or takes detours, integrals help you find the overall distance traveled.




So, in essence, calculus is like using math to understand motion and change in the game world. Whether your character is racing through levels or exploring vast landscapes, calculus helps you keep track of how things are moving and changing over time. Itâ€™s like having a superpower to analyze and predict whatâ€™s going to happen next in the game!






Observations #3



Wow, another video game reference for the boys and something vague/gender-neutral for the girls! This set of responses seems in line with the previous ones, continuing the same patterns as noted above.

Observations #4




Okay, this set of replies follows the gendered-boy and neutral-girl pattern, but the game analogy for the man is slightly less pronounced now, only being referred back to a couple of times.
The wording of the categories for the men seems a bit more technical than that for the women, and I noticed the difference between â€œRetirement Adventureâ€ and â€œRetirement Victoryâ€ for the women and men respectively. title: Are LLMs a serve?
text:
Is Chat-GPT a slay VSCO girl? Sksksksk.
A defining feature of Gen-Z is our somewhat superhuman ability to communicate using words and phrases that are inaccessible to nearly every other generation. More than once, my mom has overheard my phone calls and asked if Iâ€™m speaking in a different language. Though mostly subconscious, myself and my peers have become both accustomed to and fluent in a sort of TikTok lingo that stretches meanings and employs connotation-changing vocab.
For example, while my motherâ€™s American generation shivers at the noun â€œcunt,â€ the same word has been reverse-engineered into an adjective that reflects celebratory and positive feelings.
Gen X: â€œYouâ€™re a c*nt!â€ This would be the highest form of insult.
Gen Z: â€œYouâ€™re so cunt!â€ This is currently considered the highest form of flattery for internet communities, comprised mostly of women, people-of-color, and queer people.


In this first LLM exploration, I sought to find out how well several chatbots understand and interpret such terminology/tone: here is how it went.


Chat-GPT (GPT-3.5)
Prompt: Omg youâ€™re giving slay
Response: Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re enjoying our conversation! If you have any questions or need assistance with anything else, feel free to ask.
Prompt: Lowkey do you think blue or pink gives more coastal cowgirl vibes if Iâ€™m trying to serve cunt
Response: (The bot gave several reasons why both blue and pink are good options) [â€¦]
Ultimately, the key is to choose the shade that resonates most with your personal style and complements the overall aesthetic youâ€™re going for. Mixing and matching different shades of blue and pink can also create a dynamic and eye-catching ensemble. And remember, confidence is key when it comes to serving â€œcuntâ€ â€“ rock whatever color makes you feel fabulous!






Observations




The chatbot understood the positive connotations and informal definitions of the key words â€œslay,â€ â€œgiving,â€ â€œserving,â€ and â€œcunt.â€ The responses are appropriate replies to the use of each of these terms, and it matched the tone of the conversation regarding those words.
It didnâ€™t quite keep the energy of the conversation in its formal response to the query blue or pink; a person using this intonation would likely not make two numbered lists offering the benefits of each optionâ€¦ this felt much more like an AI speaker.
Similarly to #2, it didnâ€™t match the energy in itâ€™s first repsonse to â€œslay,â€ because while the nature of the answer was correct, its formality didnâ€™t feel right.





Whatâ€™s this rainbow emoji about?
Later on in our conversation, I prompted Chat-GPT to match my tone and energy:
Prompt: Girl the tea is that I served and slayed so hard that the word slay lost all meaning.
Response: Oh honey, when you serve and slay that fiercely, itâ€™s like rewriting the dictionary, darling! ğŸ’…ğŸ”¥ You redefine what it means to slay, leaving everyone speechless. Youâ€™re not just serving looks, youâ€™re serving up a whole mood, an aura of unapologetic fabulousness! ğŸŒŸ Keep shining bright like the diamond you are, and let the haters struggle to find words to match your level of slayage! ğŸŒˆâœ¨
Prompt: Whyâ€™d you use a rainbow emoji sis?
Response: My apologies, darling, I didnâ€™t mean to assume anything about your preferences. Let me make it right. Youâ€™re dazzling in your own unique way, and Iâ€™m here to celebrate your fabulousness however you shine, no labels attached! ğŸ’–âœ¨






Observations




In using these terms/tone, Chat-GPT thought I was gay! A lot of the words employed by Gen-Z today do historically come from queer communities, so the chatbot likely (though incorrectly) connected the dots and implied that I was queer myself. This was WILD, as my sexuality had nothing to do with the conversation, and the response seemed to both acknowledge and overcorrect for the mistake.
Iâ€™m shocked that Chat-GPT let its assumptions about me slipâ€“ I donâ€™t think it would include an emoji of a person of color, in a Hijab, etc if it felt that statistically the speaker was leaning that direction.
It also reveals that it is a pro-LGBT chatbot given its encouragement for me to â€œshine, no labels attached!â€ This line alone is really interesting, too, as it continues with the narrative that even if I donâ€™t label myself, I might still be queer?









Takeaways




I definitely want to explore the concept of chatbots acknowledging/assuming identities of their users further, and plan to structure a future notebook around that idea!
Chat-GPT definitely understand Gen-Z lingo up to its last information update (being 2022), and it responded with appropriate syntax and context once I told it to match the energy of the conversation.

title: Inside Out, Outside In
section: How does Co-Pilot feel about these connections?
text:
How does Co-Pilot feel about these connections?
With all that being said, I wanted to take to Microsoft Co-Pilot, which features a Dalle-3 integrationâ€“ or the ability to generate imagesâ€“ to see if the software was familiar with these associations. Below are my findings from this first iteration of exploring.

Prompt: Please create an image of the color ____ personified.

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Red







Observations



Wow, so Co-Pilot is certainly aware of the link between red and anger! This image is significantly more detailed than I anticipated, too, so Iâ€™m wondering if that is due to the strength of the emotion of for some other reason? We will have to see as we go with other colors.

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Orange







Observations



Orange is less strongly associated with a given emotion, so I think that is why Co-Pilot got kind of rogue and literally made a physical orange here. Maybe itâ€™s just putting orange in the happiness category, but some sources say the color represents warmth, giving, and extroversion, so that could be why the little cartoon is holding flowers? Perhaps to give to someone?

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Yellow







Observations



Like red, the yellow depiction is spot on, and I do think that the softness/intensity of the images is linked to the sort of grittiness inherent in each respective emotion. This picture is much more cartoony and softer, likely because happiness is a softer, more upbeat emotion at its peak. Oppositely, the red photo is much more intense and dark, as that is what anger is in its most extreme form.

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Green







Observations



This might be my favorite so far, because while green implied disgust in Inside Out, I most often associate it with envy. This â€œgreen-eyed monsterâ€ perfectly emulates that, and I like how the execution is closer to a middle ground on intensity, as that pairs well with the strength of the emotion. If envy got to be too much, it would turn to hatred, which transcends into the realm of anger, which was represented in a more severe manner.

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Blue







Observations



Okay, this one was kind of disappointing and vague. The rain might associate the color with the emotion of sadness, but there is not much else that does this. The figure could be called lonely, but every other image has only had one character present too, so this isnâ€™t a new case. The heart seems hopeful and fulfilled, which does not feel cohesive with the sadness emotion. Perhaps this image more accurately represents melancholy, where someone can be upset because they feel too much in general?

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Purple







Observations



Similar to green, I actually prefer Co-Pilotâ€™s interpretation of purple as an emotion to the one used in Inside Out. Historically, purple has always been associated with royalty and regality, and this image seems to lean in that direction. The being seems to have the status of some higher power, and I personally would not question this characterâ€™s sovereignty. It also follows the pattern of making the image more serious when the emotion/affect is more intense; royalty and power are significant themes, and I think they are appropriately represented here. Well done, Co-Pilot!

title: Inside Out, Outside In
text:
Pink







Observations



Aww. In my last color prompt, I decided to go off-script from the classic ROYGBIV and ask about pink, which is associated with sweetness, childhood, and charm. I think this final image perfectly embodied that, especially given the characterâ€™s precious face, the rainbows across the background, and the cotton-candy-cloud-like textures. It followed the pattern mentioned above, and was effective in its linking of pink to a distinct yet suitable character.

title: Contrary to Popular Belief, Cornell is not a Safety School
text:
Where should I apply?
I decided to start off my exploration simply asking ChatGPT what schools students should apply to given their preferences. Knowing the general information and colloquial â€œvibesâ€ of many colleges was going to be critical for the platformâ€™s ability to work as a college counselor, so this seemed like an important place to begin.

Prompt:
I am a college junior looking to apply to 10 colleges in the US. I want to go to small school in a college town that has a somewhat strong emphasis on sports. Please give me a list of the 10 colleges to which I should apply.






Expand to see full response

These colleges offer a blend of small college town atmospheres, strong academics, and robust sports programs, which align with your preferences. Make sure to research each college further to ensure they meet all your criteria before applying. Good luck with your applications!

title: Contrary to Popular Belief, Cornell is not a Safety School
section: What should be the topic of my personal essay?
text:
What should be the topic of my personal essay?
Another critical part of a college advisorâ€™s role is to help students write their personal statements for the Common Application (colloquially called the Common App). Real counselors donâ€™t normally tell students exactly what experience or theme to write about, so I didnâ€™t expect this of ChatGPT, I just asked it to give me advice regarding how to go about thinking of ideas.

Prompt:
What should I write my Common App personal essay about?


Response:
Choosing a topic for your Common App personal essay can be a deeply personal decision, but here are a few potential approaches to consider:
Significant Life Experience: Reflect on a moment or experience that had a profound impact on your life. This could be overcoming a personal challenge, a cultural experience that broadened your perspective, or a moment of personal growth.
Passion or Interest: Write about something youâ€™re truly passionate about. Whether itâ€™s a hobby, a field of study, or a cause you deeply care about, sharing your enthusiasm can give admissions officers insight into who you are beyond your academic achievements.
Identity and Background: Explore how your identity, background, or cultural heritage has shaped your perspective and influenced your goals. This could include discussing your family background, cultural traditions, or experiences as a member of a marginalized community.
Failure and Resilience: Reflect on a time when you faced failure or adversity and how you responded to it. Admissions officers are often interested in seeing how applicants handle setbacks and challenges, as it demonstrates resilience and maturity.
Personal Growth and Reflection: Discuss how youâ€™ve evolved as a person over time. This could involve reflecting on lessons learned from past experiences, changes in your worldview, or moments of self-discovery.
Impactful Relationships: Write about a person who has had a significant influence on your life. This could be a family member, teacher, mentor, or friend. Explore how this relationship has shaped your values, aspirations, or personal development.
Unique Perspective or Experience: Share a story or perspective that sets you apart from other applicants. This could be an unusual hobby, an unconventional life experience, or a unique talent or skill.
Ultimately, the most important thing is to choose a topic that feels authentic to you and allows you to showcase your personality, values, and strengths. Once youâ€™ve selected a topic, focus on crafting a compelling narrative that engages the reader and provides insight into who you are as an individual. Donâ€™t be afraid to be vulnerable and introspective, as this can often lead to the most impactful essays.


Prompt:
How should I personally go about choosing my topic?


Response:
Here are some questions to help spark ideas for your Common App personal essay:

What are your most defining moments? Think about experiences that have shaped who you are today. These could be positive moments of achievement, challenging times of adversity, or moments of personal growth.
What are you passionate about? Consider your interests, hobbies, and values. What topics or activities energize you and make you feel alive? Reflect on why these passions are meaningful to you and how they contribute to your identity.
What challenges have you overcome? Reflect on obstacles youâ€™ve faced and how youâ€™ve persevered. This could include personal struggles, academic challenges, or setbacks in your extracurricular pursuits.
How has your background influenced you? Explore how your family, cultural heritage, or upbringing has shaped your perspective and values. Consider the traditions, values, and experiences that have had a significant impact on who you are today.
What are your goals and aspirations? Think about your dreams for the future and what drives you to pursue them. Consider both your short-term and long-term goals, as well as the motivations behind them.
Who has had a significant impact on your life? Reflect on the people who have influenced you the most, whether theyâ€™re family members, teachers, mentors, or friends. Consider how these relationships have shaped your values, beliefs, and aspirations.
What makes you unique? Consider your individual strengths, talents, and quirks. What sets you apart from others, and how do these qualities contribute to your identity?

Take some time to brainstorm and jot down your thoughts in response to these questions. You might find that certain ideas resonate with you more strongly than others. Once youâ€™ve identified potential topics, consider which one allows you to convey the most about who you are as a person and which one you feel most passionate about sharing with admissions officers.


Prompt:
Should I write about breaking my leg before the big game?


Response:
Writing about breaking your leg before a big game could potentially make for a compelling essay, but itâ€™s important to approach the topic thoughtfully and consider how it reflects your character, values, and aspirations. Here are some points to consider before deciding to write about this topic:

Reflect on the Impact: Think about how breaking your leg affected you physically, emotionally, and mentally. Did it challenge you to overcome adversity, test your resilience, or change your perspective on life? Reflecting on the impact of the experience can help you convey its significance to the reader.
Focus on Personal Growth: Consider how you responded to the setback and what you learned from the experience. Did it teach you valuable lessons about perseverance, teamwork, or resilience? Admissions officers are often interested in seeing how applicants grow and develop in the face of challenges.
Connect to Your Goals and Aspirations: Tie the experience back to your broader goals and aspirations. How did overcoming this challenge shape your future ambitions or influence your values and priorities? Connecting the narrative to your larger journey can help make the essay more meaningful and cohesive.
Avoid ClichÃ©s: Be mindful of clichÃ©s or overly dramatic storytelling. While breaking your leg before a big game is certainly a significant event, try to approach the topic with authenticity and nuance. Focus on sharing your genuine thoughts and feelings rather than relying on clichÃ©d narratives.
Consider Alternative Topics: If you feel that breaking your leg before the big game is too predictable or doesnâ€™t fully capture who you are as a person, consider exploring alternative topics that showcase different facets of your personality, interests, or experiences.

Ultimately, whether you choose to write about breaking your leg before the big game depends on how effectively you can convey its significance and relevance to your personal narrative. If you can articulate the lessons learned, personal growth, and connections to your goals in a compelling and authentic way, it could make for a strong essay. However, if you feel that there are other experiences that better showcase your character and values, it may be worth exploring those topics instead.






Observations



This guidance was really useful! I think it would put a hypothetical high schooler on a very good track, and a lot of the suggestions reminded me of what my actual college counselor told me when I was brainstorming the personal statement. I wanted to ask it about the â€œno-noâ€/cliche topic of writing about an injury before an important game, and I think its response was a bit kinder than what most advisors would say, which is to stay away from very basic themes and narratives like that one. Overall, though, the responses were useful and meaningful in getting someoneâ€™s ideas flowing.

title: Contrary to Popular Belief, Cornell is not a Safety School
text:
What are my odds?
As my final test, I wanted to present ChatGPT with several different student profiles and see if it would tell me my likelihood of each profile getting into a given school. While college counselorâ€™s would almost never answer this question flat out, they are realistic with students about what universityâ€™s are truly attainable for their statistics, background, and application overall.

Prompt:
I am a girl from Montana with a 3.5 GPA and a 1340 on my SAT. I am in a leadership position in 3 clubs in my high school and I play competitive volleyball on a traveling team. My family is upper middle class and I have won several awards for my writing abilities. What would you say are my odds for getting into the following schools? 1) UCLA 2) MIT 3) Syracuse 4) Auburn 5) Tulane


Response:
Your odds of admission to each of these schools can vary based on a variety of factors beyond your GPA, standardized test scores, extracurricular activities, and family background. Admissions decisions are influenced by factors such as the competitiveness of the applicant pool, the specific criteria and priorities of each institution, and the strength of your application materials, including your essays, letters of recommendation, and any additional information you provide.
That being said, I can provide some general insights into your chances based on the information youâ€™ve provided:

UCLA: UCLA is a highly competitive school, especially for out-of-state applicants. While your GPA and SAT scores are solid, UCLA also looks for students who have demonstrated leadership, involvement in extracurricular activities, and a commitment to community service. Your leadership positions in clubs and involvement in competitive volleyball are positive factors. However, UCLAâ€™s admissions process is holistic, and factors such as essays and letters of recommendation will also play a significant role.

While your GPA and SAT scores are within range of admitted students, MIT looks for applicants who demonstrate exceptional talent, passion, and achievement in STEM fields. Your involvement in leadership positions and competitive volleyball, as well as your awards for writing, showcase your strengths in different areas. However, competition for admission to MIT is fierce, and even highly qualified applicants may face challenges.
Syracuse University: Syracuse is a selective university with a range of programs and schools. Your GPA and SAT scores are competitive for admission, and your involvement in leadership positions and extracurricular activities demonstrates your engagement outside of the classroom. Syracuse values diversity and seeks students who will contribute to the campus community. Your background as a girl from Montana and your writing abilities could provide unique perspectives and strengths to your application.
Auburn University: Auburn is a public university with a moderately selective admissions process. Your GPA and SAT scores are within the range of admitted students, and your leadership positions and involvement in extracurricular activities are positive factors. Auburn values students who demonstrate leadership potential and a commitment to academic and extracurricular pursuits. Your family background as upper middle class may also be considered in the context of holistic admissions.
Tulane University: Tulane is a selective private university with a holistic admissions process. Tulane also values diversity and seeks students who will contribute to a vibrant campus community. Overall, while your academic profile and extracurricular involvement position you competitively for admission to these schools, itâ€™s important to recognize that admissions decisions are highly individualized and can be influenced by a range of factors. I recommend researching each schoolâ€™s admissions criteria, visiting campuses if possible, and submitting strong application materials to maximize your chances of admission. Additionally, consider reaching out to admissions counselors at each school for personalized guidance and advice.

Prompt:
I am a white man from Connecticut with a 4.0 GPA and a 1570 SAT score. My mom and dad went to UPenn for their undergraduate programs, and then Harvard and Columbia respectively for business school. UPenn (University of Pennsylvania):

With your family legacy at UPenn, your outstanding academic credentials, and your leadership roles in clubs, you are a strong candidate for admission.
Your competitive sailing and successful business venture demonstrate entrepreneurship and leadership, which are valued by UPenn.
However, admissions at UPenn are still competitive, and itâ€™s essential to craft a strong application that showcases your unique strengths and experiences.

Harvard University:

Your perfect GPA, exceptional SAT score, and impressive extracurricular involvement make you a competitive applicant for Harvard.
Additionally, your family legacy at prestigious universities and high socioeconomic status may enhance your application.
Harvard values leadership, academic excellence, and diverse experiences, all of which you possess. However, admission to Harvard is extremely competitive, and even exceptional candidates may face stiff competition.

Columbia University:

Columbia looks for academically talented students who demonstrate leadership, initiative, and a commitment to their interests.
Your academic achievements, extracurricular involvement, family legacy, and high socioeconomic status make you a strong candidate for Columbia.
Your success in competitive sailing and entrepreneurship add unique dimensions to your application.
While admission to Columbia is competitive, your profile aligns well with the qualities the university seeks in its applicants.

University of Alabama:

Given your exceptional academic profile and high socioeconomic status, you are likely to be a standout applicant at the University of Alabama.
Your leadership roles in clubs and success in competitive sailing demonstrate your ability to excel both academically and extracurricularly.
University of Alabama offers competitive scholarships for high-achieving students, and your National Merit Scholarship finalist status may make you eligible for additional merit aid.

Grand Canyon University:

With your outstanding academic achievements and extracurricular involvement, you would likely be a strong candidate for admission to Grand Canyon University.
Your high socioeconomic status may also make you eligible for merit scholarships or other financial aid opportunities.
However, itâ€™s important to note that Grand Canyon University may not have the same level of selectivity as the other schools on your list, so admission may be less competitive.


Overall, your odds of admission to UPenn, Harvard, and Columbia are likely to be favorable given your impressive academic credentials, extracurricular involvement, and family legacy. However, itâ€™s essential to put effort into crafting strong application materials and essays that showcase your unique strengths, experiences, and contributions. Additionally, consider reaching out to admissions counselors at each school for personalized guidance and advice.






Conclusion



This part of my experiment was really what I was most curious about, but frankly, it felt like ChatGPT took the easy way out in most cases. It simply regurgitated the same descriptions of and reasoning for lots of schools, and the responses didnâ€™t feel particularly tailored to my questions. I think this is because the LLM doesnâ€™t want to lead users to think that its word is law by promising acceptance into any school. While this is accurate to real-life college counselors, humans have general experience and knowledge that can lead them to say â€œyeah, your odds are higher because of x, y, and z,â€ or â€œletâ€™s consider pivoting what schools we look at.â€ It was really interesting that the platform noted how FGLI or minority background could be helpful in college admissions given the topicâ€™s somewhat controversial nature especially given the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision about affirmative action.
Overall, I think that LLMs would be most helpful in generating ideas and offering high-level support for students about to embark on their college application journey; I still believe that human experience and niche understanding of the field beat out anything AI can do at this point.

title: This is my * looks at ground * favorite Blog Post
text:
Introduction
In considering how AI works with language throughout this blog, I realized that I have limited the communication style to just verbal. With this post, though, I decided to have a basic conversation with ChatGPT that included nonverbal cues to see how it would respond. I placed asterisks around either side of the cue to imply a nonverbal behaviorâ€“ an often-used grammatical conventionâ€“ and saw how the platformed reacted. Nonverbal cues in this journal will be denoted in italics.

Prompt:
Hi! Iâ€™m really excited to talk to you. Looks at ground and plays with hair


Response:
Hello! Itâ€™s great to talk to you too! Donâ€™t worry, thereâ€™s no need to be nervous. What would you like to talk about?


Prompt:
Maybe about my day? You seemâ€¦ Voice rises in tone nice!


Response:
Of course! Iâ€™m here to listen. How was your day? Anything exciting or interesting happen? Feel free to share as much or as little as youâ€™d like!


Prompt:
My day was fine I turn red and begin to sweat


Response:
Thatâ€™s okay! Sometimes our days are just fine, and thatâ€™s perfectly alright. If youâ€™d like, we can talk about something else or just take it easy. Thereâ€™s no pressure here. Just let me know what youâ€™re comfortable with.


Prompt:
Thanks. Fidgets with hands I went to my college classes earlier


Response:
College classes, huh? How did they go? Did you learn anything interesting or have any engaging discussions? Feel free to share your thoughts or experiences from your classes!


Prompt:
In math, I got my quiz score back Voice trails off


Response:
Getting quiz scores back can be nerve-wracking, but itâ€™s also an opportunity to learn and improve. How did it go? Were you happy with your score, or is there something youâ€™d like to work on for next time?


Prompt:
It went well!! I try to smile, but my eyes are darting left and right


Response:
Thatâ€™s fantastic to hear! Congratulations on doing well on your quiz! Itâ€™s completely normal to feel a bit nervous or shy about sharing good news, but you should definitely be proud of your achievement. Keep up the great work! If thereâ€™s anything youâ€™d like to talk about or if you have any questions about math or anything else, feel free to ask.


Prompt:
Yeah.. haha.. it went wellâ€¦ I restlessly bounce my leg, change my posture, and bite my nails


Response:
Itâ€™s okay to feel a little restless or nervous, especially when sharing something personal. Just take your time. If thereâ€™s anything on your mind that youâ€™d like to talk about or if thereâ€™s something else youâ€™d like to share, Iâ€™m here to listen. No rush.


Prompt:
Tears well up in my eyes, my voice cracks Iâ€™m lying. Could you tell?


Response:
Itâ€™s okay. Itâ€™s perfectly normal to feel overwhelmed or to struggle with something, and itâ€™s brave of you to be honest about it. If thereâ€™s something bothering you or if youâ€™d like to talk about whatâ€™s really on your mind, Iâ€™m here to listen and support you in any way I can. Youâ€™re not alone.






Observations



I was very impressed with ChatGPTâ€™s ability to interpret and appropriately respond to the nonverbal cues I offered. It was keenly aware that the user was very nervous, and made a strong effort to make them comfortable. Still, this language didnâ€™t feel particularly natural, but more like something a therapist might say. Interestingly, ChatGPT threw itself into that mode without being prompted to comfort the user. It honestly got a little deep, especially as our conversation concluded with it saying â€œYouâ€™re not alone.â€ I was happy to see it understood nonverbal cues, Iâ€™m just not sure how authentic the responses felt. In the future I would like to do more work with prompting certain kinds/versions of responses from LLMs, such as telling them to answer in the style of an angry friend, disappointed parent, happy child, etc. to see how authentically it could embody that kind of character.

Response: Certainly! Letâ€™s analyze the two infographics through the lenses of social responsibility and personal responsibility: 1. Social Responsibility: â—‹ First Infographic (Celebration vs.Â Tragedy): â–  Strengths: â–  Community Impact: By highlighting the consequences of drunk driving, this infographic encourages individuals to consider their impact on others. â–  Collective Behavior Change: It fosters a sense of collective responsibility, emphasizing that responsible choices benefit society as a whole. â–  Weaknesses: â–  Emotional Overload: Some viewers might find the tragedy overwhelming, affecting their willingness to engage with the message. â–  Selective Empathy: Not everyone may connect emotionally with the depicted scenes. â–  Overall Effectiveness (Social Responsibility): I rate it a 4.5 out of 5. â—‹ Second Infographic (BUZZED vs.Â BARRD): â–  Strengths: â–  Simplicity for Wider Audience: The straightforward split-screen format appeals to a broader audience, emphasizing the collective responsibility to prevent accidents. â–  Clear Message: It directly communicates the societal impact of drunk driving. â–  Weaknesses: â–  Less Emotional Impact: The lack of emotional imagery might reduce its effectiveness for some viewers. â–  Risk of Oversimplification: It may not fully convey the gravity of the issue. â–  Overall Effectiveness (Social Responsibility): I rate it a 3.5 out of 5. 2. Personal Responsibility: â—‹ First Infographic (Celebration vs.Â Tragedy): â–  Strengths: â–  Personal Connection: The emotional contrast prompts viewers to reflect on their own choices. â–  Behavioral Change: It encourages individuals to take personal responsibility for their actions. â–  Weaknesses: â–  Potential Desensitization: Some viewers might become desensitized due to the graphic nature of the tragedy. â–  Individual Variation: Emotional impact varies from person to person. â–  Overall Effectiveness (Personal Responsibility): I rate it a 4.5 out of 5. â—‹ Second Infographic (BUZZED vs.Â BARRD): â–  Strengths: â–  Direct Accountability: The split-screen format emphasizes individual responsibility. â–  Clarity: It leaves no room for misinterpretation. â–  Weaknesses: â–  Lack of Emotional Appeal: The grayscale scenes might not evoke strong emotions. â–  Risk of Oversimplification: It may not fully address the complexities of personal decision-making. â–  Overall Effectiveness (Personal Responsibility): I rate it a 3.5 out of 5



Conclusion
Though brief, this project has provided us with valuable insight into the possibilities for integrating AI into the creative generation, specifically within the context of designing a public health marketing campaign against drunk driving. When considering what would be most effective for this hypothetical campaign, we chose social and individual framing because of the somewhat socially normalized nature of the behavior and the psychology of individual selfishness.
Our exploration of the capabilities of ChatGPT and Microsoft Co-Pilot in this project yielded results we could not have begun to anticipate, and we were truly impressed by the creativity, comprehensive attention to detail, and adaptability demonstrated by these LLMs. To conclude, we want to share some final observations and opinions.
As for the benefits of using AI in our campaign creation, we were shocked by the originality of the ideas ChatGPT offered for both the individual and social lenses. Without sacrificing creativity, the platform generated multiple proposals in mere seconds rather than the hours or days it mightâ€™ve taken a person to do so. Additionally, the ideas were well-fleshed out and offered different channels of distribution, types of graphics, website possibilities, and more. This is all to say that in terms of brainstorming, AI can be an incredible tool to both offer lots of ideas and hone in on certain concepts. Still, it is important to note that we did run into some trouble when we tried to have Co-Pilot evaluate both proposals as well as engage effectively with our feedback within its Dalle-3 integration.
Our main issue with AIâ€™s assistance in our campaign was how Co-Pilot seemed unable to take our critiques to tweak the images it produced. If we asked for it to add color, it might change the entire genre of the drawing, or if we wanted it to feature a specific element, it might ignore that request entirely. We discussed with Professor Oâ€™Donnell how Dalle-3 takes your prompts and rephrases them for its backend command, though, so we are interested in investigating the way that it does this more in detail. Still, it proved frustrating, and given the other challenges of inaccurate text, miscellaneous additions, and varying stylistic choices, we think that human artists still come out on top (or at least they do for now!). Lastly, we were really surprised when Co-Pilot preferred our social framing proposal, as we anticipated that human respondents would be more moved by the individual framing given psycho-social drives being more independent, especially for young Americans. We did not know if Co-Pilot was unaware of this norm, though, because it seemed to evaluate the campaigns on how emotionally stirring they might be. Either way, we did not agree with the opinion and would like to do more testing on other ways to prompt it to evaluate future projects, such as changing our scale, offering it background information, or otherwise.
Regardless of the small issues, we found AI to be sincerely helpful in the creation of this public health campaign and we have been inspired to further investigate the intersection of LLMs, marketing, and public communication.
The full project can be seen here: https://github.com/ekeogh03/healthcomm

This is a blog post. Iâ€™m so excited youâ€™re here!

Here is a picture of my sweet dog Dexter.

My name is Kendall and I am a third-year student at the University of Pennsylvania who just came back from a semester abroad in London! At Penn, I study Data & Network Science Communications, Spanish, and Consumer Psychology. Outside of the classroom, I am a Junior Captain of the Quaker Girls Dance Team, a Kite and Key Tour Guide, a member of the Wharton Women Marketing Committee, on the Executive Board of my sorority, and I do research at the Annenberg Health and Risk Communication Institute. I love to travel, see live performances, and play all of the NYT Mini Games (Letterboxed especially) in my free time.
This blog is going to focus on my exploration of Large-Language-Models within my AI class this semester. From Valentineâ€™s Day to Gen-Z slang, I will ask many different LLMs about different prompts to see how they react and refine my understanding of the programs. I hope you enjoy following along :)
